why are there multiple JSON standards? I thought ECMA-404 was the "canonical" JSON standard but apparently IETF has its own JSON?
everyone considers their own standard canonical!
well, let me rephrase, I thought JSON was TC39's domain...
a musical canon of standards / a round of JSON?
* a musical canon of standards / a round of JSON?

m.new_content.body: a musical canon of standards / a round of JSON?

content.body: I see them as complimentary standards. ECMA402 is very conservative, describes syntax mechanically, doesn't add much editorial fluff or advisory information
wonder if there's any difference between the two standards: if the IETF standard is a subset/profile then I guess that's not _that_ unexpected.
content.formatted_body: wonder if there's any difference between the two standards: if the IETF standard is a subset/profile then I guess that's not that unexpected.

content.body: I use 8259 when I need to show people why it's a bad idea to use the complete grammar in ECMA-404
* I see them as complimentary standards. ECMA404 is very conservative, describes syntax mechanically, doesn't add much editorial fluff or advisory information

m.new_content.body: I see them as complimentary standards. ECMA404 is very conservative, describes syntax mechanically, doesn't add much editorial fluff or advisory information

content.body: e.g. if you expect precision greater than IEEE754 doubles, , you're going to have a bad time, and RFC8259 helpfully calls that out
